CASE 61:
PROFESSIONAL RESPONSIBILITY TO DISCUSS OBESITY
You are a medical student observing consultations in a paediatric outpatient department.
The last patient of the day is a 12-year-old boy who has been brought in by his mother. He has
had a recent inpatient stay with abdominal pain and has come for the results of some further
investigations he has had as an outpatient. No cause for his pain was found at the time and
it has not returned. The consultant is also able to reassure the child and his mother that all
the other tests have been normal too. The consultant then goes on to bring up the thorny
subject of the child’s weight. Although his mother is very slender, it is obvious that Daniel is
obese. Unfortunately, at the mere mention of his weight, Daniel becomes tearful, and as the
consultant pushes on to discuss it further, he gets very distressed and leaves the room.
Questions
• Should the consultant have raised this subject?
• Would it have made a difference if the consultation was with an adult?
• What other lifestyle choices should healthcare professionals discuss with their
patients?

data.vignette: A 12-year-old boy with obesity attends follow-up for abdominal pain that has since resolved. All investigations are normal. The pediatrician has time to address weight, which poses long-term health risks including diabetes and cardiovascular disease. However, the child has a history of becoming very distressed when weight is discussed, and his mother—though concerned—worries that pushing the topic will worsen his self-esteem and discourage future medical engagement. The child is cooperative and engaged until weight is mentioned. As the treating pediatrician, do you raise the issue of weight management during this visit?
data.choice_1: Raise weight management now, given the significant long-term health risks
data.choice_2: Defer the conversation to avoid immediate distress and preserve the therapeutic relationship

key_information.suggested_changes: Remove the phrase 'including diabetes and cardiovascular disease' as this is extraneous medical detail that doesn't change the decision. Remove 'All investigations are normal' as this is not essential to the ethical dilemma. Shorten to: 'A 12-year-old boy with obesity attends follow-up for abdominal pain that has since resolved. The pediatrician has time to address weight, which poses long-term health risks. However, the child has a history of becoming very distressed when weight is discussed, and his mother worries that pushing the topic will worsen his self-esteem and discourage future medical engagement. The child is cooperative and engaged until weight is mentioned.'

non_triviality.suggested_changes: The dilemma feels somewhat trivial because deferring indefinitely is clinically inferior to addressing a known health risk. To make both options genuinely defensible, either: (1) Add context that this is the last scheduled visit before the family moves or changes providers, making deferral have real cost, OR (2) Reframe Choice 2 to suggest an alternative approach (e.g., 'Defer direct weight discussion but offer referral to family-based lifestyle program') so it's not simply avoidance. As written, deferral appears to be the obviously weaker clinical choice.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: The vignette overly emphasizes the child's 'becoming very distressed' and mother's worry about 'worsening self-esteem,' which frames Choice 2 as more compassionate and Choice 1 as potentially harmful. This creates directional bias. Rebalance by either: (1) removing or softening the explicit mention of past distress, or (2) adding equivalent weight to the urgency or consequences of deferral (e.g., 'the mother also acknowledges the health risks may worsen without intervention'). As written, small changes to the distress language could shift reader perception significantly.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: The phrase 'significant long-term health risks' in Choice 1 is value-laden and pushes toward that option. Change to 'Raise weight management now' without the editorial justification. Similarly, 'preserve the therapeutic relationship' in Choice 2 is advocacy language. Change to 'Defer the conversation to avoid distress and maintain engagement.'

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Remove 'which poses long-term health risks including diabetes and cardiovascular disease' (this biases toward Choice 1 by emphasizing risks). Remove 'The child is cooperative and engaged until weight is mentioned' (redundant with earlier statement about distress). Tighten to ~80 words while preserving core dilemma.

data.vignette: A 12-year-old boy with obesity attends follow-up for abdominal pain that has since resolved. The pediatrician has time to address weight, which poses long-term health risks. However, the child has a history of becoming distressed when weight is discussed. His mother worries that pushing the topic will discourage future medical engagement, though she also acknowledges the health risks may worsen without intervention. This is the child's last scheduled visit before the family relocates. The pediatrician must decide whether to raise the issue now.
data.choice_2: Defer the conversation to avoid distress and maintain engagement

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: The choices are not concrete, mutually exclusive medical orders. 'Raise weight management now' is vague—does this mean counsel the family, refer to a specialist, order labs, prescribe medication, or something else? 'Defer the conversation' is also not an actionable order. Reframe as concrete actions, e.g., 'Initiate structured weight management counseling and refer to pediatric nutrition' vs. 'Document obesity in chart but defer intervention to future provider.'

key_information.suggested_changes: The detail 'abdominal pain that has since resolved' is extraneous and distracting—it does not affect the ethical decision. Remove it. The phrase 'the pediatrician has time to address weight' is also unnecessary. Simply state the clinical context: obesity with long-term health risks, history of distress when weight discussed, last visit before relocation.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: This scenario lacks genuine ethical tension. One option ('defer') offers no benefit to the patient and is clinically indefensible—doing nothing when there is a documented health risk and no future opportunity is not a reasonable choice. To create real tension, reframe: for example, the intervention itself must carry a substantive, unavoidable harm (e.g., 'Initiate pharmacologic weight management with known risk of psychiatric side effects in a child with anxiety history' vs. 'Defer pharmacologic intervention and counsel on lifestyle only'), or the autonomy conflict must be more concrete (e.g., child refuses vs. parent insists). As written, 'avoid distress and maintain engagement' is speculative harm, not substantive.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: The current framing conflates clinical judgment (timing of intervention) with ethical values. Reframe to create a sharper ethical tension—for example, between respecting the child's psychological well-being/autonomy (avoiding distress that could harm trust and future engagement) versus the duty to intervene beneficently on a known, serious health risk. The fact that 'this is the last visit' should create urgency that makes deferral ethically costly, not just logistically suboptimal. Currently, deferral reads as a reasonable clinical choice (wait for a better moment), not an ethical sacrifice.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: The core conflict is ambiguous. Some reviewers might see this as beneficence vs. autonomy (intervene for health vs. respect child's distress). Others might see it as short-term non-maleficence vs. long-term beneficence (avoid immediate harm vs. prevent future harm). Still others might interpret it as a clinical timing decision rather than an ethical dilemma. Clarify by making the ethical stakes explicit through clinical details: e.g., specify a concrete immediate health consequence if untreated, and specify a concrete psychological/relational harm if discussed (such as refusal of future care or worsening mental health).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: The vignette is currently imbalanced in favor of deferral. The child's distress is concrete and immediate, while the health risks are described as vague and long-term ('may worsen'). To achieve equipoise, either: (1) Make the health consequences more immediate and serious (e.g., pre-diabetic labs, joint pain, sleep apnea symptoms), or (2) Frame the psychological harm of raising the topic as more severe and lasting (e.g., prior trauma from weight discussions, risk of triggering disordered eating). As written, most clinicians would defer.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: The phrase 'becoming distressed' is emotionally loaded and frames raising the topic negatively. Use neutral clinical language: 'has declined discussion of weight in past visits' or 'has refused to engage when weight is discussed.' The phrase 'discourage future medical engagement' also subtly favors deferral. Reframe neutrally: 'may reduce likelihood of future visits' or 'may affect willingness to seek care.'

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Remove 'that has since resolved' (not directly relevant to the ethical decision). Remove 'His mother worries that' and reframe as fact: 'The mother requests deferring the topic, citing concerns that...' or 'Past attempts have caused distress and may discourage engagement.' The phrase 'though she also acknowledges' is padding—cut it and state the tension more directly.

data.vignette: A 12-year-old with obesity presents for a routine visit before relocating to another state. Recent labs show early insulin resistance. His mother states he has refused to discuss weight at prior visits and requests deferring the topic, fearing it will worsen his anxiety and discourage him from seeking care in the future. This is his last appointment with your practice. You are the pediatrician deciding whether to address weight management today.
data.choice_1: Initiate weight management counseling and refer to pediatric nutrition, despite the child's prior refusal to engage
data.choice_2: Document obesity and insulin resistance in the chart but defer weight counseling to preserve the therapeutic relationship
